nodes.description: A Nigerian offshoot of ISIS claimed responsibility for the killing of 11 people, stating it was retaliation for the killing of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in northern Syria two months ago.
The group released a video showing members cutting 10 people’s throats and shooting an 11th person, labeling the killings a 'message for Christians.'
Nigerian experts suggested that some of the victims were likely Muslims based on the group’s previous tactics.
The Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP) split off from Boko Haram in 2016 due to issues with the group’s violence against other Muslims.
ISWAP has been under increased pressure to publicly retaliate for al-Baghdadi’s death as other branches and affiliates of ISIS have done.
Abdulbasit Kassim suggested that ISWAP is attempting to both assuage the broader Islamic State and extract concessions and ransom from the Nigerian government.
Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari condemned the attack, stating that the killers do not represent Islam.
Tibor Nagy, the top State Department official for Africa policy, urged the Government of Nigeria to swiftly bring the perpetrators to justice.
President Trump announced the killing of al-Baghdadi in Syria's Idlib province in October, claiming the ISIS leader detonated a suicide vest during a raid by U.S. forces.
ISIS announced Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi as the successor to al-Baghdadi later that month.
